awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Predicting how climate change will impact insect adaptation to host plant resistance
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Insect herbivore evolution is tightly linked to changes in their host plants. Many plants possess defensive traits (e.g., induced production of toxic secondary metabolites) that enable them to naturally tolerate and/or deter insect herbivory. However, fluctuations in trait expression may promote insect adaptations to overcome these defenses (virulence). Climate factors associated with global climate change can disrupt plant defense expression, subsequently altering plant susceptibility to insect herbivores. Whether these changes also affect the development of virulence remains unknown, an important knowledge gap that this project aims to fill. Understanding these evolutionary interactions is critical for preserving global food security. Within agricultural production systems, insect resistant crops enhance plant productivity, but virulence threatens their longevity as a sustainable pest management tool. Results from this project will be broadly disseminated, with outreach efforts focused on increasing public awareness about insect resistant crops. The Fellow will develop and disseminate learning modules to high school students in traditionally underserved groups, and additional outreach to agricultural stakeholders will help growers consider genetically modified and naturally resistant crops when making planting decisions.

Using soybeans and soybean aphids as a model system, the project will characterize how one abiotic factor, water stress, impacts aphid adaptation to host plant resistance (HPR). Soybean phytohormone concentrations will be used as a marker to determine how combined aphid and water stress interact to alter HPR expression. The Fellow will then assess how these abiotic-induced changes to soybeans impact aphids by comparing fitness in virulent and susceptible aphids using life table analyses. Concurrent RNA sequencing will also characterize aphid stress gene expression under the different climate scenarios. Finally, experimental mesocosms will test whether water stress alters the frequency of virulence within an aphid population. Collectively, these experiments are expected to directly link host plant climate stress to population level responses in aphids, improving our understanding of the mechanisms by which climate change may facilitate virulence. Throughout this project, the Fellow will expand technical skills through training in molecular biology and bioinformatics. Additional professional skills will be developed through participation in mentorship training programs and outreach to non-academic audiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Host plant resistant (HPR) crops provide an effective and sustainable form of insect pest management. Yet, some insects have adapted to overcome these defenses (i.e. virulence), which threatens the efficacy of HPR crop cultivars. Abiotic stressors associated with global climate change may also impact HPR trait expression, which potentially introduces a selective pressure onto virulent and avirulent insect populations that threaten the long-term durability of HPR. To advance our understanding about these evolutionary consequences, Margaret Lewis completed her NSF postdoctoral research project “Predicting how climate change will impact insect adaptation to host plant resistance” at the Ohio State University in Columbus, OH.

 

Using soybeans and the invasive, pestiferous soybean aphid as model system, Lewis investigated how flooding, an abiotic stressor predicted to intensify under global climate change, alters soybean – aphid interactions across different trophic levels. Through a collaboration with the OARDC Metabolite Analysis Center (OMAC), Lewis quantified how different combinations of soybean aphid infestation and flooding interacted to affect soybean phytohormone concentrations as a marker for soybean plant defenses. Regardless of aphid infestation treatment, flooding in soybeans increased concentrations of Jasmonic Acid (JA) in a Rag1+2 aphid-resistant soybean variety. The JA signaling pathway is known to control the expression of HPR traits in soybean, suggesting that flooding may enhance HPR trait expression. Beyond JA, flooding also influenced the expression of indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) and abscisic acid (ABA) in both aphid-susceptible and aphid-resistant soybean varieties. These data indicate that flooding does alter the quality of soybeans as a host plant for aphids, which in turn affects soybean aphid fitness. Overall, we observed a differential fitness response to flooding between virulent and avirulent soybean aphid biotypes. Avirulent (i.e. susceptible to HPR soybean) soybean aphids were negatively impacted by flooding; they experienced decreased population growth rates with flooding and also had elevated expression for various stress-related genes. In contrast, virulent aphid responses to flooding were muted; neither population growth rates or gene expression patterns changed in response to flooding. Collectively, our study results suggest that virulent aphids may be better adapted to handle host plant flooding stress. As global climate change effects intensify, these adaptations may confer a fitness advantage for virulent soybean aphid biotypes that allows them to build their populations at a faster rate. This may threaten the long-term adoption of HPR soybean as a sustainable aphid management tactic.

 

In addition to her research, Lewis also collaborated with GrowNextGen, a non-profit organization, to develop various K-12 education materials as part of the broader impacts portion of her fellowship. These materials include an e-learning course on insect life cycles that has been made freely available online, an online simulation of aphid population dynamics, a classroom activity that mimics the process of selectively breeding for aphid resistance traits in soybeans using starburst candies, and classroom experiments that allow K-12 students to compare how different soybean varieties impact aphid population growth rates. Lewis has presented these materials to K-12 educators through various venues, including conferences and training workshops. Working with GrowNextGen, Lewis also helped to create a video about careers in entomology in which she discussed her typical job duties, research goals, and challenges that her field faces. This video has been made freely available online and aims to stimulate student interest in agricultural and STEM careers.

 

Throughout the project period, Lewis received considerable professional development and training. She expanded her research skills, for example learning how to perform metabolite analysis and how to analyze large genomic datasets. She gave multiple presentations at scientific conferences, department seminars, and outreach events, expanding her ability to communicate to a broad variety of audiences. She also gained skills in project management. Five undergraduate students were mentored as part of this project. Students received training in insect rearing and experimental manipulation, molecular laboratory techniques (i.e. DNA extraction and PCR), and data analysis.
